column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column13: A continued focus on our pay parity practices has meant that we have also achieved our pay parity gap target of less than 1%. Continuing our membership of NAWO (National Association of Women in Operations) and Meat Business Women Australia, we launched mentoring and upward mentoring pilots in our meat business.

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column13: Our Gender Equity Network ran a Hackathon for International WomenÃ¢ÂÂs Day with support from Accenture. It attracted more than 70 store support centre team members who spent a day creating and pitching ideas to progress gender equity at Coles, including the winning teamÃ¢ÂÂs pitch of Ã¢ÂÂbe the lead for a week,Ã¢ÂÂ where women get the chance to experience their managerÃ¢ÂÂs role including a seat at the table for leadership meetings and decisions.

column6: Parental leave
column7: Coles is committed to supporting working families. In FY23, Coles announced changes to our Paid Parental Leave Policy. These focused on strengthening and expanding the support available to our team members who may be primary or secondary carers preparing for parenthood, adjusting to being a new parent or experiencing loss.

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
column7: Coles adopts a proactive approach to industrial relations focused on direct engagement with team members, including notice and effective consultation processes when major organisational change is proposed. Coles maintains several enterprise agreements that govern a significant percentage of our team member workforce, and specified notice and consultation provisions are contained within those relevant agreements.

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
column13:
ColesÃ¢ÂÂ safety strategy, Ã¢ÂÂSafer Choices TogetherÃ¢ÂÂ, has four key pillars that drive delivery of our Health, Safety and Wellbeing Plan (the
Plan). The Plan is focused on:
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Safe, sustainable leadership: all Coles team members can make safe decisions to promote a positive safety culture.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Smarter safety: more competent protection through data, technology, innovation and agile working methods.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Healthy teams: an environment where injured team members are supported to return to work.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Mind your health: to create communities where we are seen, heard, and matter.
column20: Safe Sustainable Leadership, Smarter Safety, Healthy Teams, & Mind Your Health

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Our Safety Management System, Ã¢ÂÂSafetyCAREÃ¢ÂÂ, supports the Plan and is integrated into ColesÃ¢ÂÂ operations, providing a framework for managing risks and hazards, helping look after the health, safety and wellbeing of our team members, customers, contractors, suppliers and visitors, and early and influential injury management assistance to team members injured through work.
column20: SafetyCARE, Managing Risks and Hazards, Health, Safety, and Wellbeing

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Health and safety committees in stores and distribution centres also meet monthly to review and discuss safety performance, manage risks and implement corrective actions from proactive safety hazard checks. The hazard checks allow for the regular review of risks and hazards and enable team members to raise any additional threats. They are reviewed at site health and safety committee meetings, where the level of risk is evaluated, and corrective actions are implemented to eliminate or manage the risk.
column20: Health and Safety Committees, Proactive Safety Hazards Checks, Corrective Actions

column6: Occupational health services
column13: In FY23, we introduced a new safety metric that comprises crucial lead and lag safety indicators applicable to all business units. The Index includes TRIFR and other metrics involving proactively identifying and managing safety risks, including training, return to work and early intervention programs.
column20: Safety Metric, TRIFR, Proactive Identification

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: To support our leaders in improving our safety performance and culture, they are provided with regular safety performance updates and take part in management reviews to identify areas for action and improvement. Monthly safety reporting is provided to the Board, Audit and Risk Committee, Executive Leadership, and operational leadership teams.
column20: Safety Performance and Culture, Monthly Safety Reporting, the Board, the Executive Leadership Team, and Operational Leadership Teams.

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: In FY23, Coles again ran a company-wide safety week that focused on safety coaching moments and actions to be taken to ensure the safety of all team members and customers. The themes for safety week were Ã¢ÂÂSee Something, Do SomethingÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂWhen you have a Choice, Choose SafetyÃ¢ÂÂ, with leaders and team members encouraged to recognise and reward team members who displayed safe behaviours.
column20: Company-Wide Safety Week, Safety Coaching Moments, Ensure the Safety of all team

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: We continued to develop our team, with more than 88,000 team members and leaders completing online and face-to-face safety training programs. This training covered key risk areas such as manual handling, hazard identification, cleaning and hygiene, use of mobile plant and traffic management.
column20: Team Members and Leaders, Online and Face-to-Face Safety Training programmes, Manual Handling

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: We continued our focus on situations where a public member threatens a team memberÃ¢ÂÂs safety. In FY23, we established a cross-functional working group to strengthen our risk control measures, including face-to-face de-escalation training, duress devices and communication systems to be used in emergencies, and the use of security guards. We also collaborate with other retailers, industry bodies and unions on shared initiatives.

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: In addition to reducing the number of team member injuries that occurred in FY23, we continued to help injured team members return to work with the support of our early intervention medical provider. There was a 5% reduction in team members working reduced hours or duties during the year.
column20: Member Injuries, Early Intervention Medical Provider, 5% Reduction

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: We reviewed our risk profile quarterly and updated 18 risk assessments and 126 safety system documents in FY23 to ensure hazards are mitigated, and controls align with current operational requirements and legislation. These reviews are completed in consultation with team members through site health and safety committees and involve reviews of risk assessments, SafetyCARE procedures, forms and tools, safe work practices and training documents.

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: To target a reduction in critical risks, several safety initiatives were launched. Installation of low hoist skirts across our Supermarket fleet to remove the risk of persons accessing underneath the equipment, which during operation could lead to significant injury or death.

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: Over 400 project manager site safety audits and 137 independent construction audits were completed. column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: Senior leaders could participate in a full health check with a medical provider to support and improve their physical and mental well-being.
